docs.title: PhenoteFX: A tool for annotating the Human Phenotype Ontology
docs.text:
PhenoteFX is a Desktop Java App for working with Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) Annotation data. It is designed to help curators revise or create phenotype annotation records for Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) rare disease data. PhenoteFX is currently at version 0.8.5 and can be downloaded at its GitHub repository.

PhenoteFX - overview

docs.title: Feedback
docs.text: The best place to leave feedback, ask questions, and report bugs is the PhenoteFX Issue Tracker.

docs.title: Authors
docs.text:
• Peter N. Robinson
  • Daniel Danis

docs.title: For developers
docs.text: PhenoteFX is a JavaFX application. See the installation instructions for information on how to run PhenoteFX as a JAR file. The following text describes how to create native images with GraalVM

docs.title: GraalVM
docs.text:
First download the correct GraalVM version for your platform. For the instructions to install the code.

https://graalvm.github.io/native-build-tools/latest/maven-plugin.html

docs.title: mkdocs
docs.text:
To generate the documentaiton locally, create a Python virtural environment and install mkdoc and packages as follows, and then start the local mkdocs server.

python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip install --upgrade pip
pip install mkdocs-material
pip install mkdocs-material[imaging]
pip install pillow cairosvg
pip install mkdocs-material-extensions
pip install mkdocstrings[python]
mkdocs serve

docs.title: Use the prebuilt Jar file
docs.text:
Simply download the latest release of PhenoteFX from the GitHub releases page at https://github.com/monarch-initiative/PhenoteFX/releases.

!!! 

This is the recommended way of installing for normal users.

docs.title: Install from Source
docs.text: You only need to install from source if you want to contribute to the development of PhenoteFX yourself. To use PhenoteFX for annotation, it is recommended to download the prebuilt version.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
For building PhenoteFX, you will need

  • Java JDK 21 or higher <http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html>_ for compiling PhenoteFX,
  • Maven <http://maven.apache.org/>_ for building PhenoteFX, and
  • Git <http://git-scm.com/>_ for getting the sources.

docs.title: Git Checkout
docs.text:
The following command downloads the sources of PhenoteFX.

git clone https://github.com/monarch-initiative/PhenoteFX.git

docs.title: Building
docs.text:
You can build PhenoteFX using mvn package.

cd PhenoteFX
mvn package

You shuld now be able to start the app with the following command.

java -jar target/PhenoteFX.jar

docs.title: Maven Proxy Settings
docs.text:
If you are behind a proxy, you may encounter problems with Maven downloading dependencies. Edit the settings.xml file in your .m2 maven directory to adjust the settings for your proxy server.

<settings>
  <proxies>
   <proxy>
      <active>true</active>
      <protocol>http</protocol>
      <host>proxy.example.com</host>
      <port>8080</port>
      <nonProxyHosts>*.example.com</nonProxyHosts>
    </proxy>
  </proxies>
</settings>

docs.title: Adding annotations
docs.text:
The PhenoteFX app requires each annotation to have a citation from PubMed. Therefore, the first thing to do is to grab the pubmed id from the article you are curating.

For this example, we will use data from Klopocki E, et al. (2008_) A microduplication of the long range SHH limb regulator (ZRS) is associated with triphalangeal thumb-polysyndactyly syndrome. J Med Genet. 45:370-5.

The corresponding ID that PhenoteFX expects is PMID:18178630 (no space in between PMID: and the number, but PhenoteFX will automatically remove spaces when you paste the id into the dialog).

PhenoteFX - specifying the PubMed id

Paste the PMID into the source field, as shown above.

Now we can add the first annotation. In this case, we will add the mode of inheritance as Autosomal dominant inheritance HP:0000006. Note that if we type some letters into the HPO Term field, PhenoteFX will autocomplete the term if it can.

PhenoteFX - Autocomplete

If you hit the enter button, the term will be chosen. Then click on the Add annotation button.

PhenoteFX - Autosomal dominant

This adds the annotation to the curation file. The PMID is now stored as the default value and does not need to be changed unless you want to switch to a new citation.

PhenoteFX - Features

We can see the clinical features to annotate in Table 1 of PMID:18178630. For instance, 11 of 12 affected individuals had Triphalangeal thumb HP:0001199. We can enter the frequency data as follows (and click the Add annotation button to enter the annotation). Note that in this case, the context of the article implies that if a + is not shown inthe table, the individual did not have the feature in question. This may not always be the case and the curator should read the article to be able to accurately curate the data.

PhenoteFX - Annotating triphalangeal thumb

We continue entering features in this way. The table states that five individuals had syndactly. However, the text states that individuals in the family had cutaneous/osseous syndactyly of fingers III–V or IV/V. We do not have further details, and we typically curate with as much detail as possible given the data in the original publication. To search for a more detailed syndactyly term, we can use the HPO ontology browser on the top right of PhenoteFX.

PhenoteFX - Ontology Browser

From this, we choose the term Finger syndactyly HP:0006101.

PhenoteFX - annotations

The above figure shows the appearance of PhenoteFX after we have entered several annotations. When we are finished, we can use the Save or Save and Close items in the File menu to save our work - see filemenu.

docs.title: Create a new entry
docs.text:
To create a new entry, use the New item from the File menu. This opens a new dialog, where you can enter the OMIM id (just the 6-digit number) and the disease name (it is easiest to use copy paste for both operations). When you are done, click "OK".

Create a new disease entry (file)

docs.title: PhenoteFX File Menu
docs.text:
Use the file menu to start a new curation file, open an existing one, or save your work.

PhenoteFX file menu
  • New Start a new curation file.
  • Open Open an existing curation file using a standard file-system browser
  • Open by MIM number If you have stored your files as OMIM:**.tab, where **** stands for the OMIM identifier, then this command will open a file if you enter the OMIM number. The command only works for files stored in the PhenoteFX default directory (see :ref:tutorial_setup).
  • Close Close the current file. You will be asked if you want to save work if applicable.
  • Save & Close Save the current file and then close it.
  • Save As Save the current file using a standard system browser and optionally change the file name.
  • Quit PhenoteFX Exit the app.

docs.title: Using a local copy of the HPO for annotations
docs.text:
This is an option for power users that most users should not require.

In many cases, new term requests on the HPO GitHub issue tracker contain both a new term request as well as a list of diseases that should be annotated with the new term. It would be nice to annotate the diseases at the same time as we make new terms. However, PhenoteFX uses the release version of the hp.json file by default; since this file is updated only about once a month, we would have to wait to annotate the diseases.

Instead, PhenoteFX is able to use a local copy of the hp.json file that has been created from the most up-to-date edit file of the HPO (hp-edit.owl).

docs.title: How to create a local hp.obo version
docs.text: Please see the tutorial at http://hpo-workbench.readthedocs.io/en/latest/latest.html We are working on making this slightly easier.

docs.title: Setting up PhenoteFX
docs.text:
When you use PhenoteFX for the first time, you need to download some files and tell PhenoteFX where you would like to store the annotation files.

PhenoteFX setup menu. Use it to perform the following commands.

docs.title: Download HPO
docs.text: This will download the latest release of hp.obo from the HPO GitHub page.

docs.title: Set Biocurator ID
docs.text: Enter whatever you would like be be nano-attributed by, e.g., MGM:rrabbit.

docs.title: Set default directory for phenoteFX files
docs.text: This will be the directory where you store the HPO annotation filess. Each annotated disease will have its own file that will be named OMIM-123456.tab (for the corresponding OMIM id).

docs.title: Show settings
docs.text: This item opens a window to show the current settings and allows the settings entered in the previous three steps to be checked.

docs.title: Sharing curation files
docs.text: The files that are created and saved in this way will be saved in the default PhenoteFX directory - see setup. They are tab-separated text files that can be opened in Microsoft Excel if desired. Share these files with the HPO team to submit new disease annotations for including the HPO resource.

docs.title: Text mining
docs.text:
PhenoteFX can also help to annotate patients one at a time starting from clinical vignettes (short descriptions). In the following example, we use the description of individual 1 from

For this example, we will use data from Wieczorek D, et al. (2010) A specific mutation in the distant sonic hedgehog (SHH) cis-regulator (ZRS) causes Werner mesomelic syndrome (WMS) while complete ZRS duplications underlie Haas type polysyndactyly and preaxial polydactyly (PPD) with or without triphalangeal thumb. Hum Mutat 31:81-9

To perform text mining, click the Add to cohort button.

PhenoteFX - text mining

Now, paste the relevant text into the dialog that appears, click the Analyze button.

PhenoteFX - text mining

Confirm the relevant findings by adding a check mark (or drag and drop to the exluded findings list below). Here, we have also used the browser to add the term Tonic pupil HP:0012074 <https://hpo.jax.org/app/browse/term/HP:0012074>_, which the text mining algorithm did not pick up.

PhenoteFX - text mining

Finally, click on Add selected terms to get the final list of terms for the current individual.

PhenoteFX - text mining

When you are satisfied with the terms, click on the Confirm & close button.

docs.title: One or multiple individuals
docs.text: Text mining can be used for one patient or for a cohort of patients. If you use it for a cohort of patients, then click on the Add to cohort button for each patient until you are done.

docs.title: Finalizing text mining
docs.text:
To transfer the text mined results to the main PhenoteFX application, click on the Finish button.

PhenoteFX - text mining

docs.title: Adjusting results
docs.text:
To add more information or edit a line, you can right click on many of the fields (Onset, Frequency, Sex, Pub, Evidence). For instance, here we have right-clicked on a frequency and could change the frequency.

PhenoteFX - text mining
